en_first_half: It is said that passion makes one think in a circle. Certainly with hideous iteration the bitten lips of Dorian Gray shaped and reshaped those subtle words that dealt with soul and sense, till he had found in them the full expression, as it were, of his mood, and justified, by intellectual approval, passions that without such justification would still have dominated his temper. From cell to cell of his brain crept the one thought; and the wild desire to live, most terrible of all man’s appetites, quickened
en_second_half: into force each trembling nerve and fibre. Ugliness that had once been hateful to him because it made things real, became dear to him now for that very reason. Ugliness was the one reality. The coarse brawl, the loathsome den, the crude violence of disordered life, the very vileness of thief and outcast, were more vivid, in their intense actuality of impression, than all the gracious shapes of art, the dreamy shadows of song. They were what he needed for forgetfulness. In three days he would be free.
en_results_raw: As the wild desire to live quickened within him, Dorian Gray felt the weight of his own existence pressing down upon him. The relentless pursuit of beauty and pleasure had become a prison, one he could not escape. The mirror that had once reflected the face of a young and handsome man now held the visage of a man ravaged by time and sin. Each day, he found himself drawn deeper into a cycle of self-destruction, his actions driven by a desire to avoid the inevitable consequences of his choices. The world outside his opulent London home seemed distant, almost unreal, as he became increasingly isolated from those around him. His friends and acquaintances, once drawn to his charm and wit, now found themselves repelled by the darkness that had consumed him. Yet, despite the growing isolation, Dorian clung to the hope that there might be a way to break free from the cycle of passion and despair that had become his life. He sought solace in the company of artists and writers, hoping to find in their works a glimpse of redemption. But as the years passed, the only thing that remained constant was the relentless pursuit of pleasure, and the ever-present fear that the truth of his soul would be revealed to the world. In the end, Dorian Gray's fate was sealed by the very passions that had once driven him, and the story of his life became a cautionary tale of the dangers of unchecked desire and the pursuit of beauty at any cost.
